This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures, and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for BEPCs Lonesome Creek Station.
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
Basin Electric Power Cooperative (BEPC) is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our accidental release prevention program that encompasses design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training. Engineering controls are in place to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. The Lonesome Creek Generating Station is a non-responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan.
The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
BEPCs Lonesome Creek Station (LCS) is a natural gas-fired peaking station located northwest of Williston. The facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as part of the Selective Catalytic Reduction process. Anhydrous ammonia is stored in two interconnected tanks, each containing a maximum of 8,500 labs of ammonia. Since LCS has more than 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, it is required to submit a Risk Management Plan ("RMP") and comply with the requirements of 40 C.F.R. Part 68. 
The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:
The BEPC LCS RMP Program is led by an RMP Management Team dedicated to the establishment of management systems that successfully implement the various elements of the Program. BEPC has a program in place to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. The facility is subject to the Program 3 requirements for anhydrous ammonia. The following sections briefly d

escribe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Process Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.65]
BEPC maintains a record of process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis [40 CFR Part 68.67]
Comprehensive analyses ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.69]
To ensure safe operations, BEPC maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Employee Training [40 CFR Part 68.71]
BEPC has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating plant processes are competent in the applicable operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity [40 CFR Part 68.73]
BEPC carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Inspected process equipment include pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, pressure relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change [MOC] [40 CF

R Part 68.75]
Written procedures are in place at BEPC to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. Facility operators or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification(s).

Pre-Startup Safety Review [PSSR] [40 CFR Part 68.77]
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications to existing processes are conducted routinely at BEPC. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.79]
BEPC conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the US EPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.81]
BEPC promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum period of 5 years.

Employee Participation [40 CFR Part 68.83]
BEPC believes that Process Safety Management and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, BEPC employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP and PSM rules, including information resulting from Process Hazard Analyses in particular.

Hot Work Permit [40 CFR Part 68.85]
BEPC has a hot work permit that requires issuance of a hot work perm

it for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process. 

Contractor Safety Program [40 CFR Part 68.87] 
BEPC occasionally hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. BEPC has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards associated with the contractor's work and the corresponding processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.
The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
The BEPC LCS facility has not had any RMP reportable accidents.
The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
BEPC LCS maintains an Emergency Action Plan along with periodic training that details procedures for how to handle emergency situations quickly and effectively with minimum hazard to the employees involved. In addition to protecting employee safety, the procedures are in place to minimize damage to equipment, minimize interruption of operations, and coordinate outside response to emergency situations. BEPC LCS is also included in the community emergency response plan and appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response. 
Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
The facility will ensure that the employees are fully trained in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia process, emergency response, chemical and equipment hazards, and all the requirements of the Program prior to working on the ammonia process. At the time of this submission, BEPC has addressed all recent PHA and audit recommendations and has conducted a training that details the RMP Prevention Program for all managers to ensure a well-run program. BEPC is committed to continually improving their prevention program.

BEPC has completed this report to provide the publ

ic with information about our activities at this facility.  We believe that the many controls instituted to maintain a safe operation, and our commitment to continuous improvement that an incident affecting our employees or the surrounding area is unlikely to occur.
